Electricity plays a very important role in our daily lives. Though electricity is very useful to us, it can also be very dangerous in the careless uses. Any type of faults in electrical appliances or circuits can cause fires and electric shocks. Due to the passage of electricity through the body there is a risk of death of people.
Uses of electricity can be dangerous due to three reasons described below.
1. Damaged insulation
2. Overheating of the cables
3. Damped conditions
1. Damaged insulation:
The electrical appliances work when these are connected to the voltage source by two conducting wires to complete the circuit. These two wires are called live and neutral wire. These conducting wires are usually insulated with rubber. Then they are wound together to form a cable and enclosed by PVC or rubber.
These insulating materials become worn with time and use. For example- the electrical cables of the electric iron which we use in home get bent and twisted because of the way they are used. This might cause the electrical insulation to crack and break. As a result, the conducting wires inside is exposed. If by any means a person comes into contact with the exposed live wire, it may cause severe electric shock to the user. If the live and neural wires come into mutual contact due to the damaged insulation, a short circuit will happen and may cause a fire.
2. Overheating of the cables: Overheating of cables occur when unusually large current flows through the electric cables or conducting wires. For example- an unusual
large current flows, when an electric fan motor overheats and melts, as a result the live and neutral wire is fused together. Besides this, we make connection of too many electrical devices in a wall socket by using a multi-plug. Due to this, the conducting wire connected to the socket draws more current from the main line than the current which the conducting wire can draw safely. As a result, the cable wire is overheated, insulation is melted and causes fire.
3. Damped conditions: Many electrical accidents may occur in damped conditions. We know, electricity can pass through water. The parts of an electric appliance which are not insulated must be kept dry. Otherwise, there is a risk of short circuits and electric shocks. As an example, leaving a hair dryer on a wet sink is very dangerous. The person using the sink could be electrocuted if the wires were exposed or the insulation had damaged. Besides this, switching on or off of
an electric switch by wet hand is risky.
Safe use of electricity
Figure: 11.14
In the previous section you were informed about the dangers of electricity. In the present section, we will learn about the safe uses of electricity.
When using electricity at home, the safety measures that are needed:
1. Circuit breaker
2. Fuses
3. Correct connection of switch
4. Earth wire
1. Circuit breaker
Circuit breakers are used as safety devices. Generally this is placed near the front door of a house. Circuit breaker switches off the electrical supply in a circuit when there is an overflow of current. Circuit breaker disconnects the electrical supply in a definite part of the house. Without circuit breaker in a circuit, this excessive current can cause damage of home appliances or even start a fire.
2. Fuses: A fuse is a safety device. A fuse is included in an electrical circuit to prevent excessive current flow. The fuse is always connected to the live wire of electrical cables. A short thin piece of wire is used as a fuse. The fuse becomes hot and melts when the electric current flowing through it is greater than a definite value. As a result, the circuit is disconnected and the electrical appliances will be safe. The fuse is marked with definite amount of current on its body. Fuses will be such that it can bring slightly higher current than the maximum current an electrical device or appliance can tolerate safely. If the fuse burns, the appliance will not be electrified any more. Before changing fuse, you have to switch off the mains of electricity supply.
3. Correct connection of switch: A switch breaks or completes an electrical circuit. During switch connection in a circuit, an important precaution is that the switch must be fitted onto the live wire. For this, switching off will disconnect the high voltage source from the appliance instantly [Figure 11.15]. If the switch is fitted onto the neutral wire wrongly, the electric appliance will be 'live' even if the switch is 'off' [Figure 11.16] and increase the risk of electric shock.
Figure 11.15 and 11.16
4. Earth wire: All electrical appliances or devices need at least two wires to form a complete circuit. These are the live (L) and neutral (N) wire. The live wire delivers the electrical energy to the appliance. On the contrary, the current returns back to the supply through the neutral wire and complete the circuit. The potential of neutral wire is zero. The earth wire is a low-resistance wire. It is usually connected to the metallic casing of the appliance. The circuit may be faulty from different reasons. If the live wire is not properly connected and it touches the metal casing of the appliance- the user may be electrocuted from an electric shock. Earthing of the casing prevents this from happening. In this case, the large current will flow from the live wire to the earth through the metal casing. As a result, the fuse will blow out and cut off the electric supply to the appliance. It is strongly recommended to provide an earthing to the refrigerator in houses for safe use of it. Figure 11.17 demonstrates how a washing machine without earthing may be risky. How earth wire works as a safety precaution is demonstrated in figure 11.18.

Load shedding

Each of the power stations generates a definite amount of electric power. The electricity generated by all the power stations is added in the national power grid. According to the demand of different locality power sub-stations collect electricity from the national grid. Then the power sub-station delivers or distributes the electricity to the consumer level. When in a particular area, the demand of electricity exceeds the supply or generation; the power sub-station can no longer fulfill the demand of electricity. Then the sub-station authority is forced to switch off or to disconnect the power distribution for a while in some parts of the distribution network. This is called load shedding. When the sub- station gets the supply according to its demand, then it distributes electricity in that region again. If the load shedding takes place for a couple of hours continuously, authority load sheds circularly in different area to make load shedding tolerable at the consumer level.

question: What is the difference between conventional current and electron flow? Explain with examples.
answer:
Conventional current is the flow of positive charges, while actual electric current is the flow of negative charges (electrons). 

In conventional current, the direction is from higher potential to lower potential, or from positive plate to negative plate of an electric cell. 

However, actual electric current flows from lower potential to higher potential, or from negative plate to positive plate of an electric cell. 

For example, in a battery, the positive terminal is at a higher potential than the negative terminal. In this case, conventional current would flow from the positive terminal to the negative terminal, but actual electric current flows from the negative terminal to the positive terminal.

question: Explain the concept of resistance and its dependence on different factors.
answer:
Resistance is a measure of the opposition to the flow of electric current in a conductor. It is a fundamental property of a conductor and depends on several factors:

1. **Length (L)**: Resistance increases with the length of the conductor.
2. **Cross-sectional area (A)**: Resistance decreases with the cross-sectional area of the conductor.
3. **Material**: Resistance varies with the material of the conductor, with some materials having higher resistivity than others.
4. **Temperature**: Resistance increases with temperature, as the atoms and molecules of the conductor vibrate more, causing more collisions with the electrons.

The SI unit of resistance is the ohm (Ω), and it is defined as the resistance of a conductor through which a current of 1 A flows when a potential difference of 1 V is applied across it.

The resistivity (ρ) of a conductor is a constant that depends only on its material and temperature. It is related to resistance by the equation R = ρL/A, where L is the length and A is the cross-sectional area of the conductor.

In summary, resistance is a complex property that depends on multiple factors, including length, cross-sectional area, material, and temperature.

question: What is Ohm's Law? Explain its mathematical expression and its significance.
answer:
Ohm's Law is a fundamental principle in physics that describes the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in an electric circuit. The mathematical expression of Ohm's Law is:

V = IR

Where:
- V is the potential difference (voltage) in volts (V)
- I is the electric current in amperes (A)
- R is the resistance in ohms (Ω)

This law states that the current flowing through a conductor is directly proportional to the voltage applied across it, and inversely proportional to the resistance of the conductor. The significance of Ohm's Law lies in its ability to predict the behavior of electric circuits and to calculate the required components for a given circuit configuration.

question: Explain the concepts of electromotive force (EMF) and potential difference. How are they different and how are they related?
answer:
Electromotive force (EMF) and potential difference are related but distinct concepts. EMF is the work done by an electrical energy source to drive a unit positive charge from one point to another in a circuit. It is a measure of the energy required to produce electric current. Potential difference, on the other hand, is the amount of work done to carry a unit positive charge between two points in a circuit. It is a measure of the energy converted to other forms (e.g., heat, light) when a unit positive charge migrates between the two points.

In other words, EMF is the energy source that drives the current, while potential difference is the energy that is converted as the current flows. The unit of EMF and potential difference is the same, which is the volt (V).

question: What is Ohm's Law? Explain its mathematical expression and its significance.
answer:
Ohm's Law is a fundamental principle in physics that describes the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance in an electric circuit. The mathematical expression of Ohm's Law is:

V = IR

Where:
- V is the potential difference (voltage) in volts (V)
- I is the electric current in amperes (A)
- R is the resistance in ohms (Ω)

This law states that the current flowing through a conductor is directly proportional to the voltage applied across it, and inversely proportional to the resistance of the conductor. The significance of Ohm's Law lies in its ability to predict the behavior of electric circuits and to calculate the required components for a given circuit configuration.

question: What are the key differences between series and parallel circuits? Explain with examples.
answer:
The key differences between series and parallel circuits are:

Series Circuit:
- Components are connected one after another in a single loop.
- Same current flows throughout the circuit.
- Total resistance is the sum of individual resistances.
- If one component fails, the entire circuit is broken.

Parallel Circuit:
- Components are connected between the same two points.
- Current divides among the branches, but voltage remains the same.
- Total resistance is less than the smallest individual resistance.
- If one component fails, the other branches continue to function.

Example: 
- A series circuit with two bulbs and a battery. If one bulb burns out, the circuit is broken.
- A parallel circuit with two bulbs and a battery. If one bulb burns out, the other bulb continues to function.

11.13 System loss and load shedding We know, electrical energy is produced in power stations situated at different places. The electricity thus generated has to be transmitted at different places according to the demand. The electrical energy produced is transmitted to the different substations situated at different places by the electricity transmission system. Then from different substations this electrical energy is distributed to the consumers by electricity distribution system again. In the power station the electrical energy is generated at low voltage. Then this low voltage is transformed into high voltage by the step-up transformer. The conducting wires which are used for electricity transmission have a definite amount of resistance. As a result, to overcome this resistance, part of the electrical energy is converted to heat. That is, a loss or decay of energy occurs. This loss of energy is termed as system loss. Due to the transmission of electricity at high voltage, the loss that occurs due to the power grid or of conductor is decreased to a great extent. For a definite amount of electrical energy, the value of the electric current becomes lower due to high voltage transmission. As an example- if the transmission line voltage is increased by ten times, then the electric current becomes one tenth. As a result, the i2R loss of the power grid becomes one hundredth. Therefore, by increasing the transmission line voltage we can lower the system loss.

The electric machine in which mechanical energy is converted into electrical energy is called generator. The basic principals of this machine are established on the basis of electromagnetic induction. Generator can be of two kinds. Such as

1) AC generator

2) DC generator

1. AC generator: The structure and functions of it are being discussed in the following as it is widely used: Rotatipn . i i) ﬁ‘ Slip ring > Brush

Structure : There is a field-magnet NS in it. There is rectangular coil of wire in the middle of the magnet on the soft sheet of iron (AB). The iron sheet is called armature. The armature is rotated at the uniform speed in mechanical way on the middle of the magnet. The two sides of the rectangular coil are connected to two slip rings. The two slip rings can rotate to same orbit of armature. The two carbon brushes are set in such a way that they touch the two slip rings when the armature is being rotated. The resistance R of external circuit is connected to the brushes.

Figure: 12.11 Functions: When the armature undergoes rotation, the armature coil intersect the lines of force of the magnetic field and the electromotive force is induced in the coil according to electromagnetic induction. As the two sides of the coil are connected to the external circuit a alternating current is develop in the circuit. The magnitude of induced current mainly depends on the intensity and speed of the rotation of the magnetic field. During one complete rotation of the coil the direction of the induced curent is changed once. Thus the alternating current is produced from the mechanical energy. 12.10. Transformer:

The electrical device through which the high alternating potential can be changed into low alternating potential and low potential into high potential is called transformer. This device is made on the basis electromagnetic induction. There are two kinds of transformers.

These are - 1. Step up Transformer: The transformer which converts an electric current of greater strength at a low voltage into an electric current of weaker value at high voltage is known as step up transformer.

2. Step down Transformer: The transformer which changes the high potential less electric current into low potential much electric current is step down transformer.

question: What are the functions of step-up and step-down transformers?

The functions of step-up and step-down transformers are as follows:

Step-up transformer: 
- Increases the voltage of the electrical current.
- Used for transmission of electric power over long distances.

Step-down transformer:

- Used for domestic power supply, such as radio, television, tape recorder, VCR, VCP, electric watch, etc.

question: What is the main principle behind an electromagnet?
answer: The main principle behind an electromagnet is that a magnetic field can be generated by an electric current. This is based on the principle of electromagnetic induction, where a changing magnetic field induces an electromotive force (EMF) in a conductor, causing a current to flow. The strength of the magnetic field depends on the number of turns of the coil, the current flowing through it, and the presence of a ferromagnetic core, such as iron.
referenceAnswer: An electromagnet is created by winding a coil of wire around a ferromagnetic core (like iron). When electricity flows through the coil, it generates a magnetic field, making the core a magnet. The strength of the electromagnet is directly proportional to the current flowing and the number of turns in the coil.

13.6: Development of electronics The present era is the era of electronics. Radio, television, phone, fax, camera, computer, watch etc. are the contributions of electronics. The control of electric current through vacuum tube, special type of crystals and chips is known as electronics. The history of electronics is ancient of more than hundred years. The real journey of electronics begins with the invention of Addison’s effect in 1883. When Addison was working with electric lamp, one thing was disturbing him highly. The positive end of the filament of carbon of the lamp was burning again and again. To remove this difficulty, he entered a plate by sealing it with the filament. He saw that when a positive potential is given to the plate with respect to the filament, an electric current flows through the vacuum tube. But when a negative potential is applied to the plate electric current does not flow. Addison explains this phenomenon in this way- as the emitted charge from the hot filament goes to the positive plate, so this charge is negative. If the plate is negative, it repels the emitted charge, as a result no current flows through the circuit. This is known as Addison effect. British physicist Fleming first invented the vacuum tube by using Addison effect. This tube works as a rectifier that means it changes alternating current to direct current. This is the real beginning of electronics. During this time, detector was very necessary for Marconi’s Radio. This tube fills up the need of the detector. As there were two electrodes in it, this is called diode. After two years, an American named Lee de Forest invented another vacuum tube called triode. Since it had three electrodes, it was named as triode. Besides anode and cathode, there was another electrode known as grid in it. Grid controls the flow of electric current from anode to cathode. It is wonderful that the triode can work as an amplifier. So triode plays a vital role in the development of communication.

As the armature rotates, it induces an electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, producing an alternating current (AC). The main function of a generator is to produce electrical energy from mechanical energy.

It works by rotating a coil of wire within a magnetic field, which induces an electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, producing an electric current. The direction of the current changes with each rotation, creating alternating current (AC).

question: What is a transformer, and how does it differ between step-up and step-down types?
answer: This is not part of your current syllabus
referenceAnswer: A transformer is a device that changes the voltage of alternating current (AC) using electromagnetic induction. It consists of two coils wound around a common iron core. A step-up transformer increases voltage by having more turns in the secondary coil than the primary coil. Conversely, a step-down transformer decreases voltage by having fewer turns in the secondary coil. Step-up transformers are used to transmit electricity over long distances, while step-down transformers reduce voltage for household appliances.

question: Explain the principle of electromagnetic induction and its importance in generating electricity.
answer:
Electromagnetic induction is the production of an electromotive force (EMF) across an electrical conductor in a changing magnetic field. The principle is based on Faraday's law of induction, which states that a changing magnetic field induces an EMF in a conductor. The induced EMF causes a current to flow in the conductor, which is known as the induced current.

The importance of electromagnetic induction in generating electricity lies in its ability to convert mechanical energy into electrical energy. In a generator, the mechanical energy of a rotating armature is converted into electrical energy through electromagnetic induction. This process is widely used in power plants to generate electricity for distribution to homes and industries.

Electromagnetic induction is also the basis for many electrical devices, including transformers, motors, and generators. It plays a crucial role in the efficient transmission and distribution of electricity, and its importance cannot be overstated in the field of electrical engineering.
referenceAnswer: Electromagnetic induction is the principle that a changing magnetic field can induce an electric current in a closed circuit. This principle is fundamental to the operation of generators, which convert mechanical energy into electrical energy. By rotating a coil of wire within a magnetic field, the changing magnetic flux through the coil induces an electromotive force (EMF), driving the flow of current.

question: Describe the principle behind the operation of an electric motor.
answer: The principle behind the operation of an electric motor is electromagnetic induction. When the armature coil rotates within the magnetic field, it induces an electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, causing a current to flow. This current interacts with the magnetic field, producing a force that causes the armature to rotate. The direction of the induced current changes once per rotation, resulting in an alternating current.
referenceAnswer: An electric motor uses the interaction between a magnetic field and a current-carrying conductor to convert electrical energy into mechanical energy. A coil of wire carrying current is placed within a magnetic field. The interaction between the magnetic field and the current in the coil creates a force, causing the coil to rotate. This rotation is made continuous by a commutator, which reverses the direction of the current in the coil as it rotates, ensuring constant torque.
referenceContext: Suppose a loop or coil of wire like picture 12.8(a) is used between the two poles of magnet .As the loop has returned to the opposite direction from A to B, the opposite electricity will flow between the two half of the loop or coil. question: Describe the process of electromagnetic induction, and how it is used to generate electricity.
answer:
Electromagnetic induction is the process by which a changing magnetic field induces an electric field in a conductor. This is achieved by the movement of a conductor within a magnetic field, causing a voltage to be induced in the conductor. The induced voltage is proportional to the rate of change of the magnetic field and the number of turns of the conductor.

Mathematically, the induced voltage (ε) is given by:

ε = -N(dΦ/dt)

where N is the number of turns of the conductor, Φ is the magnetic flux, and t is time.

In the context of a generator, electromagnetic induction is used to convert mechanical energy into electrical energy. When the armature of the generator rotates within the magnetic field, the magnetic flux through the armature coil changes, inducing a voltage in the coil. This voltage is then used to generate an electric current in the external circuit.

The function of a generator can be explained mathematically as:

I = ε/R

where I is the current, ε is the induced voltage, and R is the resistance of the external circuit.

In the case of a step-up transformer, the voltage of the secondary coil is given by:

V2 = V1 × (N2/N1)

where V1 is the voltage of the primary coil, N1 is the number of turns of the primary coil, N2 is the number of turns of the secondary coil, and V2 is the voltage of the secondary coil.

Given that the number of turns of the primary coil (N1) is 1000, the number of turns of the secondary coil (N2) is 50, and the voltage of the primary coil (V1) is 240V AC, the voltage of the secondary coil (V2) can be calculated as:

V2 = 240 × (50/1000) = 12V
referenceAnswer: Electromagnetic induction is the process of creating electric current in a closed circuit by a changing magnetic field.  This can be achieved by moving a magnet near the circuit, moving the circuit within a magnetic field, or changing the current in a nearby circuit. Generators utilize this principle to generate electricity by rotating a coil of wire within a magnetic field, causing a change in magnetic flux that induces a current.
referenceContext: He shows that a variable magnetic field can produce electromotive force which creats electric current through a closed circuit. The phenomena to produce electric current in a closed circuit by variable magnetic field is called electromagnetic induction.

- In a step-up transformer, the number of turns in the secondary coil is greater than that in the primary coil.
- In a step-down transformer, the number of turns in the secondary coil is less than that in the primary coil.

This results in a step-up transformer increasing the voltage and a step-down transformer decreasing the voltage.
referenceAnswer: A step-up transformer increases the voltage of alternating current (AC) by having more turns in its secondary coil than its primary coil. This is used for long-distance power transmission.  A step-down transformer reduces voltage by having fewer turns in the secondary coil. It is used to provide safe and suitable voltage for household appliances and devices.

question: How does the interaction of magnetic fields and current-carrying wires play a role in the operation of an electric motor?
answer: The interaction of magnetic fields and current-carrying wires plays a crucial role in the operation of an electric motor. When a current flows through a wire, it generates a magnetic field around the wire. In an electric motor, a coil of wire is placed within a magnetic field, causing the coil to experience a force due to the interaction between the magnetic field and the current-carrying wire. This force causes the coil to rotate, which ultimately drives the motor. The commutator helps to maintain continuous rotation by reversing the direction of the current flow in the coil as it moves around the magnetic field, allowing the motor to operate efficiently.
referenceAnswer: Electric motors use the interaction between a magnetic field and a current-carrying conductor to produce rotational motion. A coil of wire carrying current is placed within a magnetic field.  The interaction between the magnetic field and the current in the coil creates a force, causing the coil to rotate. The commutator reverses the direction of current in the coil as it rotates, ensuring continuous torque and rotation.

question: Explain how a solenoid works to create a magnetic field.
answer: A solenoid works by coiling a wire into a tight spiral and passing an electric current through it. The magnetic field lines are concentrated in the centre of the coil, creating a magnetic field similar to that of a bar magnet. When an iron rod is inserted into the solenoid, it becomes magnetized. The direction of the magnetic field can be changed by reversing the direction of the current.
referenceAnswer: A solenoid is a coil of wire. When electric current flows through the coil, it creates a magnetic field that is concentrated inside the coil, resembling the field of a bar magnet.  This magnetic field is stronger than the one created by a straight wire carrying the same current. The strength of the magnetic field can be increased by increasing the current or the number of turns in the coil.

answer: The main principle of electromagnetic induction is that a changing magnetic field induces an electric field. This phenomenon was discovered by Michael Faraday in 1831.
referenceAnswer: Electromagnetic induction is the process of generating electric current in a closed circuit by a changing magnetic field. Michael Faraday is recognized for his groundbreaking work and discovery of this principle in 1831.  He demonstrated that moving a magnet near a coil or changing the current in a nearby coil can induce a current in the closed circuit.
referenceContext: He shows that a variable magnetic field can produce electromotive force which creats electric current through a closed circuit. The phenomena to produce electric current in a closed circuit by variable magnetic field is called electromagnetic induction.

13.6: Development of electronics The present era is the era of electronics. Radio, television, phone, fax, camera, computer, watch etc. are the contributions of electronics. The control of electric current through vacuum tube, special type of crystals and chips is known as electronics. The history of electronics is ancient of more than hundred years. The real journey of electronics begins with the invention of Addison’s effect in 1883. When Addison was working with electric lamp, one thing was disturbing him highly. The positive end of the filament of carbon of the lamp was burning again and again. To remove this difficulty, he entered a plate by sealing it with the filament. He saw that when a positive potential is given to the plate with respect to the filament, an electric current flows through the vacuum tube. But when a negative potential is applied to the plate electric current does not flow. Addison explains this phenomenon in this way- as the emitted charge from the hot filament goes to the positive plate, so this charge is negative. If the plate is negative, it repels the emitted charge, as a result no current flows through the circuit. This is known as Addison effect. British physicist Fleming first invented the vacuum tube by using Addison effect. This tube works as a rectifier that means it changes alternating current to direct current. question: How does an electric motor convert electrical energy into mechanical energy?
answer: Electric motor converts electrical energy into mechanical energy through electromagnetic induction. When an electric current flows through the motor's coils, it generates a magnetic field. This magnetic field interacts with a permanent magnet or a magnetic field produced by another current, resulting in a torque that causes the motor's rotor to rotate. The rotation of the rotor is then transferred to the load, converting electrical energy into mechanical energy.

question: Explain the difference between a step-up transformer and a step-down transformer, and give an example of where each is used.
answer:
Step-up transformer and step-down transformer differ in the number of turns in their primary and secondary coils. 

In a step-up transformer, the number of turns in the secondary coil is greater than that in the primary coil. This increases the voltage of the secondary coil while decreasing the current.

In a step-down transformer, the number of turns in the secondary coil is less than that in the primary coil. This decreases the voltage of the secondary coil while increasing the current.

Example: 
- A step-up transformer is used to increase the voltage of a power supply for a long-distance transmission. For instance, a step-up transformer with 1000 turns in the primary coil and 50 turns in the secondary coil is used to step up the voltage from 240V to 12000V.
- A step-down transformer is used for domestic power supply, such as in a radio or a television. For instance, a step-down transformer with 50 turns in the primary coil and 1000 turns in the secondary coil is used to step down the voltage from 12000V to 240V.

This is used for transmitting electricity over long distances, as higher voltage reduces energy loss.  A step-down transformer reduces voltage by having fewer turns in the secondary coil. It is used to provide safe and suitable voltage for household appliances and devices. For instance, a step-up transformer is used at a power plant to increase voltage before sending electricity over long distances, and a step-down transformer is used at a substation to reduce voltage before it is distributed to homes.

question: What is the principle behind electromagnetic induction, and how is it used to generate electricity?
answer:
The principle behind electromagnetic induction is that a variable magnetic field can produce an electromotive force (EMF) which creates an electric current through a closed circuit. This is achieved by the interaction between the magnetic field and the electric current. 

The process involves the following steps:

1. A conductor (like a coil of wire) is placed in a magnetic field.
2. As the conductor moves within the magnetic field, the magnetic field induces an EMF in the conductor.
3. The EMF causes an electric current to flow in the conductor.
4. The direction of the induced current is such that it opposes the change in the magnetic field.

Electromagnetic induction is used to generate electricity in generators, which convert mechanical energy into electrical energy. In a generator, a magnetic field is produced by a rotating coil (armature) within a stationary magnetic field (field magnet). As the armature rotates, the magnetic field induces an EMF in the armature, which in turn causes an electric current to flow. This current is then collected and used to power electrical devices.
referenceAnswer: Electromagnetic induction is the principle that a changing magnetic field can induce an electric current in a closed circuit. This principle is fundamental to the operation of generators. By rotating a coil of wire within a magnetic field, the changing magnetic flux through the coil induces an electromotive force (EMF), driving the flow of current.

question: What is radioactivity?
answer: Radioactivity is the spontaneous and continuous phenomenon of emission of radioactive rays or particles from an element, resulting in the transformation of the element into a new element through nuclear disintegration.
referenceAnswer: The phenomenon of emission of radioactive rays or particles from an element is called radioactivity.
referenceContext: This radiation is now-a-days known as radioactive rays. The phenomenon of emission of radioactive rays or particles from an element is called radioactivity. Radioactive elements emit three energetic rays, namely alpha, beta and gamma. As a result they transform into lighter elements by the process of disintegration. As the Radium metal transforms into Lead step by step through radioactive disintegration. The unit which is used to measure radioactivity is named Becquerel.

13.1. Radioactivity In 1896, French scientist Henry Becquerel observes that a radiation with special penetrating power emits spontaneously from the nucleus of Uranium metal in a continuous manner. He also observes that the element that emits radiation, transforms totally into a new element. This is a nuclear event. This event is a spontaneous and continuous phenomenon and fully controlled by the nature. Any manmade external influences such as- pressure, heat, electric and magnetic field cannot stop or increase or decrease the emission of these rays. Later Madame Marie Curie (1867-1934) and her husband Pierre Curie (1859-1906) observed the similar events. They noticed that similar type of radiation also emits from the heavy elements like Polonium, Thorium and Actinium etc. This radiation is now-a-days known as radioactive rays. The phenomenon of emission of radioactive rays or particles from an element is called radioactivity. Radioactive elements emit three energetic rays, namely alpha, beta and gamma. As a result they transform into lighter elements by the process of disintegration. As the Radium metal transforms into Lead step by step through radioactive disintegration. The unit which is used to measure radioactivity is named Becquerel. 13.2. Properties of alpha, beta and gamma rays Alpha particle: Alpha particle is a Helium nucleus. There are two protons and two neutrons in its nucleus. The penetrating power of alpha particle is less; it cannot pass through 6 cm thick air. These particles are influenced by both the magnetic and electric field. These particles can create intense ionization and are very harmful and dangerous. The mass of this particle is four times than that of the Hydrogen atom and its charge is 3.2×10-19 C. Its presence can be detected by photographic films, cloud chamber and gold leaf electroscope. These particles create florescence on zinc sulphide screen. The velocity of it is 10% of the velocity of light. Beta particle: These particles are negatively charged and largely deflected by magnetic and electric field. The speed of it is 50% of the speed of light but it can be increased up to 98%. Its mass is the same as that of electron i.e. 9.11×10-31kg. Its existence can be detected by photographic film and cloud chamber. These particles can produce fluorescence. Their penetrating power is more than that of the Alpha particles. The motion of these particles can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet. Beta particles can produce enough ionization in a gas. Gamma rays: These rays are charge neutral. This is an electromagnetic wave. It is of short wavelength. It has no mass. It is not deflected by electric and magnetic field. Its speed is same to that of light, which means 3×108 ms-1. Its penetrating power is very high. It can pass through a lead sheet having a few centimeter thickness. Though its ionizing power is less, it can produce fluorescence. Its presence can be identified by photographic film, cloud chamber and Geiger–Müller counter.

13.3. Half–life of a radioactive element We can’t say which atom of a radioactive element will decay and when it will take place. But we can calculate how many atoms will decay in a particular time. A cluster of atoms is considered to study the decay of atoms. The time during which just half of the total number of radioactive atoms undergoes disintegration is called the half-life of that element. As for example, let us assume that there are 800000 atoms in a radioactive element. The time required for the decay of its half i.e. 400000 atoms to transform into a new element is known as its half-life. After a next half-life, there remains 200000 numbers of atoms. After another half-life, the number of atoms will be 100000 and thus it will continue. To make the equipment germless, to control the thickness of paper in the paper mill, to identify the presence of smoke in the fire, to verify the welding of metals, the radioactivity is being successfully used. It is also used to measure the quantity of different elements in the minerals. Even the radioactive tracers are being used successfully to diagnose diseases. The hands and number of many watches are seen glittering even in the dark. The preventive power against disease is reduced if someone keeps oneself in close-contact with excessive radioactive radiation for a long time. Man can be mentally disabled; even he may be physically invalid. The harmful effect of radioactivity can be observed from generation to generation. So the people who work with radioactive radiation should be careful. They should take proper steps to protect themselves from the excessive radioactive radiation.

Ultra sonography is a procedure that depends on the reflection of sound of high frequency. When sound wave of high frequency is reflected from an organ or muscle within the body, then an image analogous to that organ is formed in the monitor by the reflected waves. The frequency of the ultrasound is 1-10 MHz which is used for diagnosis of diseases. In an ultra sonography machine, the high frequency ultrasonic waves are produced by electrically stimulating a crystal called a transducer. In an ultra sonography machine, the ultrasonic waves are transformed into a narrow beam. Next this beam is directed toward the organ whose image is to be recorded.

)® - $= Figure: 14.3 Ultrasonography The beam is reflected, absorbed or transmitted by the organ toward which they are directed, depending on the nature of the surface they strike.

As the beam strikes an interface or boundary between tissues of varying density (e.g., muscle and blood) part of the sound waves are reflected back to the transducer as echoes. The echoes are then converted into electrical impulses that are displayed on a monitor presenting a ‘picture’ of the organ or muscle under examination. Figure: 14.3 Ultrasonography

13.1. Radioactivity In 1896, French scientist Henry Becquerel observes that a radiation with special penetrating power emits spontaneously from the nucleus of Uranium metal in a continuous manner. He also observes that the element that emits radiation, transforms totally into a new element. This is a nuclear event. This event is a spontaneous and continuous phenomenon and fully controlled by the nature. Any manmade external influences such as- pressure, heat, electric and magnetic field cannot stop or increase or decrease the emission of these rays. Later Madame Marie Curie (1867-1934) and her husband Pierre Curie (1859-1906) observed the similar events. They noticed that similar type of radiation also emits from the heavy elements like Polonium, Thorium and Actinium etc. This radiation is now-a-days known as radioactive rays. The phenomenon of emission of radioactive rays or particles from an element is called radioactivity. Radioactive elements emit three energetic rays, namely alpha, beta and gamma. As a result they transform into lighter elements by the process of disintegration. As the Radium metal transforms into Lead step by step through radioactive disintegration. The unit which is used to measure radioactivity is named Becquerel. 13.2. Properties of alpha, beta and gamma rays Alpha particle: Alpha particle is a Helium nucleus. There are two protons and two neutrons in its nucleus. The penetrating power of alpha particle is less; it cannot pass through 6 cm thick air. These particles are influenced by both the magnetic and electric field. These particles can create intense ionization and are very harmful and dangerous. The mass of this particle is four times than that of the Hydrogen atom and its charge is 3.2×10-19 C. Its presence can be detected by photographic films, cloud chamber and gold leaf electroscope. Its mass is the same as that of electron i.e. 9.11×10-31kg. Its existence can be detected by photographic film and cloud chamber. These particles can produce fluorescence. Their penetrating power is more than that of the Alpha particles. The motion of these particles can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet. Beta particles can produce enough ionization in a gas. Gamma rays: These rays are charge neutral. This is an electromagnetic wave. It is of short wavelength. It has no mass. It is not deflected by electric and magnetic field. Its speed is same to that of light, which means 3×108 ms-1. Its penetrating power is very high. It can pass through a lead sheet having a few centimeter thickness. 13.3. Half–life of a radioactive element We can’t say which atom of a radioactive element will decay and when it will take place. But we can calculate how many atoms will decay in a particular time. A cluster of atoms is considered to study the decay of atoms. The time during which just half of the total number of radioactive atoms undergoes disintegration is called the half-life of that element. As for example, let us assume that there are 800000 atoms in a radioactive element. The time required for the decay of its half i.e. 400000 atoms to transform into a new element is known as its half-life. After a next half-life, there remains 200000 numbers of atoms. question: What are the characteristics of alpha, beta, and gamma rays?
answer:
Alpha, beta, and gamma rays are the three types of radiation emitted by radioactive elements. 

Alpha rays are negatively charged particles consisting of two protons and two neutrons (Helium nucleus), with a mass four times that of a Hydrogen atom and a charge of 3.2×10-19 C. They have a low penetrating power, cannot pass through 6 cm thick air, and are deflected by both magnetic and electric fields. 

Beta rays are negatively charged particles with the same mass as an electron (9.11×10-31kg), a speed of 50% of the speed of light, and a charge of 1.6×10-19 C. They are deflected by magnetic and electric fields, have a higher penetrating power than alpha rays, and can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet. 

Gamma rays are charge-neutral, electromagnetic waves with no mass, a short wavelength, and a speed equal to that of light (3×108 ms-1). They have a high penetrating power, can pass through a few centimeter thick lead sheet, and are not deflected by electric and magnetic fields.

question: Explain the difference between analog and digital electronics.
answer:
Analog and digital electronics are two types of electronic systems that differ in the way they process and transmit information. 

Analog electronics use continuous signals to represent information, which can take any value within a certain range. These signals are continuous and can be thought of as a wave. Examples of analog signals include sound, light, temperature, and pressure. 

Digital electronics, on the other hand, use discrete signals to represent information, which can only take on specific values. These signals are discrete and can be thought of as a series of 0s and 1s. Examples of digital signals include computer data, television broadcasts, and digital images.

question: What are the three types of radioactive rays and how do they differ?
answer:
Alpha, beta, and gamma rays are the three types of radioactive rays. 

Alpha rays are Helium nuclei with two protons and two neutrons, having a mass four times that of the Hydrogen atom and a charge of 3.2×10-19 C. They have a low penetrating power, can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet, and are deflected by both magnetic and electric fields.

Beta rays are negatively charged particles with the same mass as an electron (9.11×10-31kg), having a speed of 50% of the speed of light but can be increased up to 98%. They have a higher penetrating power than alpha particles, can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet, and are deflected by both magnetic and electric fields.

Gamma rays are charge-neutral electromagnetic waves with no mass, having a speed equal to that of light (3×108 ms-1) and a high penetrating power. They are not deflected by electric and magnetic fields and can pass through a few centimeter thick lead sheet.

question: How does a microphone convert sound into an electrical signal?
answer: A microphone converts sound into an electrical signal through electromagnetic induction. When sound waves hit the diaphragm of the microphone, it causes the diaphragm to vibrate. These vibrations create a magnetic field that induces an electromotive force (EMF) in the coil of the microphone, resulting in an electrical signal.
referenceAnswer: We have already said that microphone is such a device that changes sound wave into electrical audio wave or signal. The frequency and relative amplitude of the electrical audio signal remain the same as that of the sound wave.\nThere is a moving coil and a thin metallic sheet named diaphragm in the microphone. When a person speaks through a microphone, the diaphragm vibrates by the sound wave. Diaphragm is that part of the microphone which is designed to transform the vibration of sound into electricity. The vibration of different types of sounds vibrates the diaphragm differently. This vibration makes the diaphragm move to and fro in the magnetic field. As a result, alternating electric current is induced in the moving coil. Thus microphone converts the sound energy into electrical energy. This is called audio signal.

question: What are the key differences between alpha, beta, and gamma rays?
answer:
Alpha, beta, and gamma rays differ in their properties. 

Alpha rays are positively charged, have a mass 4 times that of a hydrogen atom, and a charge of 3.2×10-19 C. They have a low penetrating power and can be stopped by a 6 cm thick air layer or a 3mm thick aluminum sheet.

Beta rays are negatively charged, have the same mass as an electron (9.11×10-31 kg), and a charge of 1.6×10-19 C. They have a higher penetrating power than alpha rays and can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet.

Gamma rays are charge neutral, have no mass, and a speed equal to that of light (3×108 ms-1). They have the highest penetrating power among the three and can pass through a few centimeter thick lead sheet.

question: Describe the evolution of electronics, highlighting the key inventions and their significance.
answer:
The evolution of electronics began with Addison's effect in 1883, where British physicist J.J. Thomson discovered that a positive potential applied to a plate with respect to a filament in a vacuum tube caused an electric current to flow. This led to the invention of the vacuum tube by British physicist J.L. Fleming, which worked as a rectifier, changing alternating current to direct current.

Later, American inventor Lee de Forest invented the triode, a vacuum tube with three electrodes, including a grid that controlled the flow of electric current. The triode played a vital role in the development of communication, as it could work as an amplifier.

However, the size and expense of vacuum tubes created problems for their use in electronic devices. The invention of the p-n junction diode and n-p-n transistor provided an alternative. The p-n junction diode was a semiconductor device that could replace vacuum tubes, while the n-p-n transistor worked as an amplifier.

The development of the integrated circuit (IC) in 1960 revolutionized electronics, allowing for the creation of millions of microscopic electronic circuits in a single chip. This led to the creation of complex devices such as computers, mobile phones, and televisions, which have transformed our lives.

The evolution of electronics has been a gradual process, with each invention building upon the previous one, leading to the development of modern electronic devices that have revolutionized communication, information, and entertainment.

The control of electric current through vacuum tube, special type of crystals and chips is known as electronics. The history of electronics is ancient of more than hundred years. The real journey of electronics begins with the invention of Addison's effect in 1883. When Addison was working with electric lamp, one thing was disturbing him highly. The positive end of the filament of carbon of the lamp was burning again and again. To remove this difficulty, he entered a plate by sealing it with the filament. He saw that when a positive potential is given to the plate with respect to the filament, an electric current flows through the vacuum tube. But when a negative potential is applied to the plate electric current does not flow. Addison explains this phenomenon in this way- as the emitted charge from the hot filament goes to the positive plate, so this charge is negative. If the plate is negative, it repels the emitted charge, as a result no current flows through the circuit. This is known as Addison effect. British physicist Fleming first invented the vacuum tube by using Addison effect. This tube works as a rectifier that means it changes alternating current to direct current. This is the real beginning of electronics. During this time, detector was very necessary for Marconi's Radio. This tube fills up the need of the detector. As there were two electrodes in it, this is called diode.

question: What are the key differences between analog and digital electronics, and what are their advantages and disadvantages?
answer:
Analog and digital electronics differ in the way they represent and process information. Analog signals are continuous and can take any value within a definite range, whereas digital signals are discrete and can only take specific values (0s and 1s). 

Advantages of analog signals: 
- Can represent a wide range of values.
- Can be easily converted to other forms of energy (e.g., light, sound).

Disadvantages of analog signals: 
- Prone to noise and interference.
- Signal quality degrades over long distances.

Advantages of digital signals: 
- Can be easily processed and stored.
- Can be transmitted over long distances without significant degradation.

Disadvantages of digital signals: 
- Can only take specific values (0s and 1s).
- Requires more complex processing and storage.

Semiconductor and Integrated Circuit Semiconductor: There are some materials (such as- silicon and germanium) which are neither good conductor nor insulator. These are called semiconductors. answer: Radioactivity is the spontaneous and continuous phenomenon of emission of radioactive rays or particles from an element. It is a nuclear event that transforms the element into a new element. Radioactivity is measured in units of Becquerel (Bq), which is defined as the number of nuclear decays per second.

The unit which is used to measure radioactivity is named Becquerel.

question: Describe the key characteristics of alpha, beta, and gamma rays.
answer:
Alpha, beta, and gamma rays are the three types of radiation emitted by radioactive elements. 

Alpha rays are negatively charged particles consisting of two protons and two neutrons (helium nucleus), with a mass four times that of a hydrogen atom and a charge of 3.2×10-19 C. They have a low penetrating power, cannot pass through 6 cm thick air, and are deflected by both magnetic and electric fields. 

Beta rays are negatively charged particles with the same mass as an electron (9.11×10-31 kg), a speed of 50% of the speed of light, and a charge of 1.6×10-19 C. They are deflected by magnetic and electric fields, have a higher penetrating power than alpha rays, and can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet. 

Gamma rays are charge-neutral, electromagnetic waves with no mass, a short wavelength, and a speed equal to that of light (3×108 ms-1). They have a high penetrating power, can pass through a few centimeter thick lead sheet, and are not deflected by electric and magnetic fields.

question: Explain the concept of half-life in relation to radioactive decay.
answer: Half-life is the time required for half of the total number of radioactive atoms in a sample to undergo radioactive decay. It is a constant value specific to each radioactive element and is a measure of the stability of the element. The half-life of a radioactive element is the time it takes for the number of radioactive atoms to decrease by half due to radioactive decay.
referenceAnswer: We can't say which atom of a radioactive element will decay and when it will take place. But we can calculate how many atoms will decay in a particular time. A cluster of atoms is considered to study the decay of atoms. The time during which just half of the total number of radioactive atoms undergoes disintegration is called the half-life of that element. As for example, let us assume that there are 800000 atoms in a radioactive element. The time required for the decay of its half i.e. 400000 atoms to transform into a new element is known as its half-life. After a next half-life, there remains 200000 numbers of atoms. After another half-life, the number of atoms will be 100000 and thus it will continue. Here a law of possibility works, which atom will disintegrate when, none can say it.

question: Describe the development of electronics, highlighting key inventions and their significance.
answer:
The development of electronics began with Addison's effect in 1883, where British physicist J.J. Thomson discovered that a positive potential applied to a plate with respect to a filament in a vacuum tube causes an electric current to flow. This led to the invention of the vacuum tube by British physicist J.L. Fleming, which worked as a rectifier, changing alternating current to direct current.

Later, American inventor Lee de Forest invented the triode, a vacuum tube with three electrodes, including a grid that controlled the flow of electric current. The triode played a vital role in the development of communication, as it could work as an amplifier.

However, the size and expense of vacuum tubes created problems for their use in electronic devices. In response, scientists searched for a semiconductor device as an alternative. They eventually invented the p-n junction diode, which was later followed by the invention of the n-p-n transistor.

The transistor, invented in the mid-20th century, works as an amplifier and has revolutionized the field of electronics. It is used in most electronic appliances, including computers, mobile phones, and televisions. The development of the transistor has led to the creation of smaller, more efficient, and more reliable electronic devices, transforming the way we live and communicate.

question: What are the key differences between analog and digital electronics, and what are their advantages and disadvantages?
answer:
Analog and digital electronics differ in the way they represent and process information. Analog signals are continuous and can take any value within a definite range, whereas digital signals are discrete and can only take specific values (0s and 1s). 

Advantages of analog signals: 
- Can represent a wide range of values.
- Can be easily converted to other forms of energy (e.g., light, sound).

Disadvantages of analog signals: 
- Prone to noise and interference.
- Signal quality degrades over long distances.

Advantages of digital signals: 
- Can be easily processed and stored.
- Can be transmitted over long distances without significant degradation.

Disadvantages of digital signals: 
- Can only take specific values (0s and 1s).
- Requires more complex processing and storage.

question: What are the key differences between alpha, beta, and gamma rays?
answer:
Alpha, beta, and gamma rays differ in their properties. 

Alpha rays are positively charged, have a mass 4 times that of a hydrogen atom, and a charge of 3.2×10-19 C. They have a low penetrating power and can be stopped by a 6 cm thick air layer or a 3mm thick aluminum sheet.

Beta rays are negatively charged, have the same mass as an electron (9.11×10-31 kg), and a charge of 1.6×10-19 C. They have a higher penetrating power than alpha rays and can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet.

Gamma rays are charge neutral, have no mass, and a speed equal to that of light (3×108 ms-1). They have the highest penetrating power among the three and can pass through a few centimeter thick lead sheet.

question: Describe the development of electronics, highlighting key inventions and their significance.
answer:
The development of electronics began with Addison's effect in 1883, where British physicist J.J. Thomson discovered that a positive potential applied to a plate with respect to a filament in a vacuum tube causes an electric current to flow. This led to the invention of the vacuum tube by British physicist J.L. Fleming, which worked as a rectifier, changing alternating current to direct current.

Later, American inventor Lee de Forest invented the triode, a vacuum tube with three electrodes, including a grid that controlled the flow of electric current. The triode played a vital role in the development of communication, as it could work as an amplifier.

However, the size and expense of vacuum tubes created problems for their use in electronic devices. In response, scientists searched for a semiconductor device as an alternative. They eventually invented the p-n junction diode, which was later followed by the invention of the n-p-n transistor.

The transistor, invented in the mid-20th century, works as an amplifier and has revolutionized the field of electronics. It is used in most electronic appliances, including computers, mobile phones, and televisions. The development of the transistor has led to the creation of smaller, more efficient, and more reliable electronic devices, transforming the way we live and communicate.
referenceAnswer:
The present era is the era of electronics. Radio, television, phone, fax, camera, computer, watch etc. are the contributions of electronics. The control of electric current through vacuum tube, special type of crystals and chips is known as electronics. The history of electronics is ancient of more than hundred years. The real journey of electronics begins with the invention of Addison's effect in 1883. When Addison was working with electric lamp, one thing was disturbing him highly. The positive end of the filament of carbon of the lamp was burning again and again. To remove this difficulty, he entered a plate by sealing it with the filament. He saw that when a positive potential is given to the plate with respect to the filament, an electric current flows through the vacuum tube. But when a negative potential is applied to the plate electric current does not flow. Addison explains this phenomenon in this way- as the emitted charge from the hot filament goes to the positive plate, so this charge is negative. If the plate is negative, it repels the emitted charge, as a result no current flows through the circuit. This is known as Addison effect. British physicist Fleming first invented the vacuum tube by using Addison effect. This tube works as a rectifier that means it changes alternating current to direct current. This is the real beginning of electronics. During this time, detector was very necessary for Marconi's Radio. This tube fills up the need of the detector. As there were two electrodes in it, this is called diode.
After two years, an American named Lee de Forest invented another vacuum tube called triode. Since it had three electrodes, it was named as triode. Besides anode and cathode, there was another electrode known as grid in it. Grid controls the flow of electric current from anode to cathode. It is wonderful that the triode can work as an amplifier. So triode plays a vital role in the development of communication.

As the size of diode and triode valves are very large, they create problem to fix them in different electronic devices. The expense of power for it is more, it is less reliable and cooling system is necessary to keep it cool. So the scientists were searching for a semiconductor device as its alternative. question: What are the key differences between analog and digital electronics, and what are their advantages and disadvantages?
answer:
Analog and digital electronics differ in the way they represent and process information. Analog signals are continuous and can take any value within a definite range, whereas digital signals are discrete and can only take specific values (0s and 1s). 

Advantages of analog signals: 
- Can represent a wide range of values.
- Can be easily converted to other forms of energy (e.g., light, sound).

Disadvantages of analog signals: 
- Prone to noise and interference.
- Signal quality degrades over long distances.

Advantages of digital signals: 
- Can be easily processed and stored.
- Can be transmitted over long distances without significant degradation.

Disadvantages of digital signals: 
- Can only take specific values (0s and 1s).
- Requires more complex processing and storage.

This event is a spontaneous and continuous phenomenon and fully controlled by the nature. question: What are the key differences between alpha, beta, and gamma rays?
answer:
Alpha, beta, and gamma rays differ in their properties. 

Alpha rays are positively charged, have a mass 4 times that of a hydrogen atom, and a charge of 3.2×10-19 C. They have a low penetrating power and can be stopped by a 6 cm thick air layer or a 3mm thick aluminum sheet.

Beta rays are negatively charged, have the same mass as an electron (9.11×10-31 kg), and a charge of 1.6×10-19 C. They have a higher penetrating power than alpha rays and can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet.

Gamma rays are charge neutral, have no mass, and a speed equal to that of light (3×108 ms-1). They have the highest penetrating power among the three and can pass through a few centimeter thick lead sheet.

13.1. Radioactivity In 1896, French scientist Henry Becquerel observes that a radiation with special penetrating power emits spontaneously from the nucleus of Uranium metal in a continuous manner. He also observes that the element that emits radiation, transforms totally into a new element. This is a nuclear event. This event is a spontaneous and continuous phenomenon and fully controlled by the nature. Any manmade external influences such as- pressure, heat, electric and magnetic field cannot stop or increase or decrease the emission of these rays. Later Madame Marie Curie (1867-1934) and her husband Pierre Curie (1859-1906) observed the similar events. They noticed that similar type of radiation also emits from the heavy elements like Polonium, Thorium and Actinium etc. This radiation is now-a-days known as radioactive rays. The phenomenon of emission of radioactive rays or particles from an element is called radioactivity. Radioactive elements emit three energetic rays, namely alpha, beta and gamma. As a result they transform into lighter elements by the process of disintegration. As the Radium metal transforms into Lead step by step through radioactive disintegration. The unit which is used to measure radioactivity is named Becquerel. 13.2. Properties of alpha, beta and gamma rays Alpha particle: Alpha particle is a Helium nucleus. There are two protons and two neutrons in its nucleus. The penetrating power of alpha particle is less; it cannot pass through 6 cm thick air. These particles are influenced by both the magnetic and electric field. These particles can create intense ionization and are very harmful and dangerous. The mass of this particle is four times than that of the Hydrogen atom and its charge is 3.2×10-19 C. Its presence can be detected by photographic films, cloud chamber and gold leaf electroscope. These particles create florescence on zinc sulphide screen. The velocity of it is 10% of the velocity of light. Beta particle: These particles are negatively charged and largely deflected by magnetic and electric field. The speed of it is 50% of the speed of light but it can be increased up to 98%. Its mass is the same as that of electron i.e. 9.11×10-31kg. Its existence can be detected by photographic film and cloud chamber. These particles can produce fluorescence. Their penetrating power is more than that of the Alpha particles. The motion of these particles can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet. Beta particles can produce enough ionization in a gas. Gamma rays: These rays are charge neutral. This is an electromagnetic wave. It is of short wavelength. It has no mass. It is not deflected by electric and magnetic field. Its speed is same to that of light, which means 3×108 ms-1. Its penetrating power is very high. It can pass through a lead sheet having a few centimeter thickness. Though its ionizing power is less, it can produce fluorescence. Its presence can be identified by photographic film, cloud chamber and Geiger–Müller counter.

question: Explain the concept of half-life in relation to radioactive decay.
answer: Half-life is the time required for half of the total number of radioactive atoms in a sample to undergo radioactive decay. It is a constant value specific to each radioactive element and is a measure of the stability of the element. The half-life of a radioactive element is the time it takes for the number of radioactive atoms to decrease by half due to radioactive decay.
referenceAnswer: We can't say which atom of a radioactive element will decay and when it will take place. But we can calculate how many atoms will decay in a particular time. A cluster of atoms is considered to study the decay of atoms. The time during which just half of the total number of radioactive atoms undergoes disintegration is called the half-life of that element. As for example, let us assume that there are 800000 atoms in a radioactive element. The time required for the decay of its half i.e. 400000 atoms to transform into a new element is known as its half-life. After a next half-life, there remains 200000 numbers of atoms. After another half-life, the number of atoms will be 100000 and thus it will continue. Here a law of possibility works, which atom will disintegrate when, none can say it.

question: What are semiconductors and how are they used in integrated circuits?
answer: Semiconductors are materials whose current conduction capacity lies between that of conductors and insulators in normal temperature. They are used in integrated circuits (ICs) as they can be easily controlled and modified to increase their current conduction capacity.
referenceAnswer:
There are some materials (such as- silicon and germanium) which are neither good conductor nor insulator. These are called semiconductors. Pure semiconductor works as an insulator when it is cold. At normal room temperature it behaves slightly as a conductor. But the conductivity of semiconductor can be increased by adding some definite elements with it. Semiconductor is divided into n-type and p- type on the basis of the elements added to it. Negative and positive charge carriers are denoted by n-type and p-type respectively. The semiconductor made by the addition of phosphorous with silicon is an example of n-type material. The presence of phosphorous atoms increases the number of negatively charged electrons which can move freely in the substance. The semiconductor made by the addition of boron with silicon is the example of p-type material. The boron atoms create gap or positive holes in the electronic structure of atom. The electrons move from one hole to another by jumping within the material.
If an n-type material is sandwiched with a p-type material, a very necessary device is developed which is called a p-n junction diode. It works as a rectifier. Diode makes the electric current unidirectional i.e. the diode transforms the alternating current (AC) into a direct
current (DC). It saves radio, TV, computer etc. to be electrified due to faulty connection.
It is necessary to amplify the electric current and voltage for various reasons. The instrument which performs this work is called an amplifier. Transistor is such a device which works as an amplifier and high speed switch. A

collector and the narrow p-type region is the base of the
transistor.

question: Explain the difference between analog and digital electronics, and provide examples of each.
answer: Analogue electronics use continuous signals to represent information, whereas digital electronics use discrete signals. Analogue signals can take any value within a definite range, whereas digital signals can only take on specific discrete values. Analogue signals are used in applications such as audio and video transmission, while digital signals are used in computers and other digital devices.

The magnitude of the quantities such as sound, light, temperature, pressure can be of any value within a definite extent. Analogue data is sent continuously. Telephone, radio, television broadcast and cable television generally send analogue data.
So the analogue signals are continuously changeable voltage or current. This voltage or current is normally changed and can receive any value between the lowest and the highest value. Analogue signal is really a sine wave. Audio and video voltages are the example of analogue signals.

question: Describe the characteristics of alpha, beta, and gamma rays, including their penetrating power, charge, and how they are detected.
answer:
Alpha particles are negatively charged, have a mass 4 times that of a hydrogen atom, and a charge of 3.2×10^-19 C. They have a velocity of 10% of the velocity of light, a penetrating power of less than 6 cm in air, and are deflected by both magnetic and electric fields. They can be detected by photographic films, cloud chambers, and gold leaf electrospheres.

Beta particles are negatively charged, have the same mass as an electron (9.11×10^-31 kg), and a charge of -1.6×10^-19 C. They have a speed of 50% of the speed of light, can be increased up to 98%, and have a penetrating power more than alpha particles. They can be stopped by a 3mm thick aluminum sheet and can produce enough ionization in a gas. They can be detected by photographic films and cloud chambers.

Gamma rays are charge-neutral, have no mass, and a speed equal to that of light (3×10^8 ms^-1). They have a high penetrating power, can pass through a few centimeter thick lead sheet, and are not deflected by electric and magnetic fields. They can be detected by photographic films, cloud chambers, and Geiger-Müller counters.

question: Describe the development of electronics, highlighting key inventions and their significance.
answer:
The development of electronics began with Addison's effect in 1883, where British physicist J.J. Thomson discovered that a positive potential applied to a plate with respect to a filament in a vacuum tube causes an electric current to flow. This led to the invention of the vacuum tube by British physicist J.L. Fleming, which worked as a rectifier, changing alternating current to direct current.

Later, American inventor Lee de Forest invented the triode, a vacuum tube with three electrodes, including a grid that controlled the flow of electric current. The triode played a vital role in the development of communication, as it could work as an amplifier.

However, the size and expense of vacuum tubes created problems for their use in electronic devices. In response, scientists searched for a semiconductor device as an alternative. They eventually invented the p-n junction diode, which was later followed by the invention of the n-p-n transistor.

The transistor, invented in the mid-20th century, works as an amplifier and has revolutionized the field of electronics. It is used in most electronic appliances, including computers, mobile phones, and televisions. The development of the transistor has led to the creation of smaller, more efficient, and more reliable electronic devices, transforming the way we live and communicate.

The present era is the era of electronics. Radio, television, phone, fax, camera, computer, watch etc. are the contributions of electronics. The control of electric current through vacuum tube, special type of crystals and chips is known as electronics. The history of electronics is ancient of more than hundred years. The real journey of electronics begins with the invention of Addison's effect in 1883. When Addison was working with electric lamp, one thing was disturbing him highly. The positive end of the filament of carbon of the lamp was burning again and again. To remove this difficulty, he entered a plate by sealing it with the filament. He saw that when a positive potential is given to the plate with respect to the filament, an electric current flows through the vacuum tube. But when a negative potential is applied to the plate electric current does not flow. Addison explains this phenomenon in this way- as the emitted charge from the hot filament goes to the positive plate, so this charge is negative. If the plate is negative, it repels the emitted charge, as a result no current flows through the circuit. This is known as Addison effect. British physicist Fleming first invented the vacuum tube by using Addison effect. This tube works as a rectifier that means it changes alternating current to direct current. As there were two electrodes in it, this is called diode.

Besides anode and cathode, there was another electrode known as grid in it. Grid controls the flow of electric current from anode to cathode. It is wonderful that the triode can work as an amplifier. So triode plays a vital role in the development of communication.

13.6: Development of electronics The present era is the era of electronics. Radio, television, phone, fax, camera, computer, watch etc. are the contributions of electronics. The control of electric current through vacuum tube, special type of crystals and chips is known as electronics. The history of electronics is ancient of more than hundred years. The real journey of electronics begins with the invention of Addison’s effect in 1883. When Addison was working with electric lamp, one thing was disturbing him highly. The positive end of the filament of carbon of the lamp was burning again and again. To remove this difficulty, he entered a plate by sealing it with the filament. He saw that when a positive potential is given to the plate with respect to the filament, an electric current flows through the vacuum tube. But when a negative potential is applied to the plate electric current does not flow. Addison explains this phenomenon in this way- as the emitted charge from the hot filament goes to the positive plate, so this charge is negative. If the plate is negative, it repels the emitted charge, as a result no current flows through the circuit. This is known as Addison effect. British physicist Fleming first invented the vacuum tube by using Addison effect. This tube works as a rectifier that means it changes alternating current to direct current. This is the real beginning of electronics. During this time, detector was very necessary for Marconi’s Radio. This tube fills up the need of the detector. As there were two electrodes in it, this is called diode. After two years, an American named Lee de Forest invented another vacuum tube called triode. Since it had three electrodes, it was named as triode. Besides anode and cathode, there was another electrode known as grid in it. Grid controls the flow of electric current from anode to cathode. It is wonderful that the triode can work as an amplifier. So triode plays a vital role in the development of communication.

13.3. Half–life of a radioactive element We can’t say which atom of a radioactive element will decay and when it will take place. But we can calculate how many atoms will decay in a particular time. A cluster of atoms is considered to study the decay of atoms. The time during which just half of the total number of radioactive atoms undergoes disintegration is called the half-life of that element. As for example, let us assume that there are 800000 atoms in a radioactive element. The time required for the decay of its half i.e. 400000 atoms to transform into a new element is known as its half-life. After a next half-life, there remains 200000 numbers of atoms. After another half-life, the number of atoms will be 100000 and thus it will continue. Here a law of possibility works, which atom will disintegrate when, none can say it. 13.4: Uses of radioactivity There are a lot of uses of radioactivity in medical science, agriculture and industries. To make the equipment germless, to control the thickness of paper in the paper mill, to identify the presence of smoke in the fire, to verify the welding of metals, the radioactivity is being successfully used.
